Posts.Content: Well, I'm home now. Everything went well...the doctor said I was a little "oozy" during the surgery. The first thing I remember in recovery is my arms and legs shaking uncontrollably. I ended up spending two nights in the hospital due to the swelling and pain. I had two bouts with nausea, one more serious than the other, but I powered through with some phenergan and support from my wonderful wife. It's been three days post surgery and I'm still having some gurgling in the gut area...mainly when I'm lying down. When I get on the toilet the gas pains decide to disappear for the most part. It it normal to have a little blood leak out of the cath tube where it inserts into the penis while you're on the toilet and slightly bearing down? Right now I'm using a walker. Have any of you guys used one post-op? I'm hoping to wean off it in the next couple of days, but it makes a great hanger for the urine bag. I'm feeling a little better each day and am looking forward to next Tuesday when I'm scheduled to get the cath out. Thanks again for the thoughts and prayers.
Posts.Title: Tomorrow's the big day

Posts.Title: Tomorrow's the big day

Posts.Content: I've got most everything packed, magnesium citrate gurgling in my gut (I know, TMI) and am feeling fairly good about tomorrow's RALP. I'm first on the docket and have to be there at 6:00 am. I'll be waking up around 3:30 or so. It's been a long five weeks since my surgery date was selected. I've lurked quite a bit and picked up a lot of great information from everyone. Thanks very much. I'll post again once I get to the other side.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind Ask your urologist how many robotic prostatectomies he has performed...If that number is less than 300, I would look for another surgeon with more experience...There is a lot riding on this.... He's been doing laparascopic surgery since 1999. To be honest, I'm not sure of the number of robotic prostatectomies he's performed.
Posts.Title: Another newbie...decided on surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Can you tell us if the Gleason 7 is a 3+4 or 4+3? It can make a difference. Thanks for the warm welcome. It is a 3 + 4. Below is the second opinion. The first pathology report had 2 cancerous cores. Diagnosis OUTSIDE SLIDES, OUTSIDE CASE # PU15-380 A. PROSTATE, LABELED AS "LEFT LATERAL BASE", CORE BIOPSY: · BENIGN PROSTATE TISSUE B. PROSTATE, LABELED AS "LEFT LATERAL MID", CORE BIOPSY: · BENIGN PROSTATE TISSUE C. PROSTATE, LABELED AS "LEFT LATERAL APEX", CORE BIOPSY: · PROSTATIC ADENOCARCINOMA · GLEASON GRADE 3+4 · INVOLVING ONE OF ONE CORE, APPROXIMATELY 30% · GLEASON GRADE 4 COMPRISES APPROXIMATELY 10% OF TUMOR · NO PERINEURAL INVASION · NO LYMPH VASCULAR INVASION D. PROSTATE, LABELED AS "LEFT MIDDLE BASE", CORE BIOPSY: · BENIGN PROSTATE TISSUE E. PROSTATE, LABELED AS "LEFT MIDDLE MID", CORE BIOPSY: · PROSTATIC ADENOCARCINOMA · GLEASON GRADE 3+4 · INVOLVING ONE OF ONE CORE, APPROXIMATELY 2% · GLEASON GRADE 4 COMPRISES APPROXIMATELY 10% OF TUMOR · NO PERINEURAL INVASION · NO LYMPH VASCULAR INVASION F. PROSTATE, LABELED AS "LEFT MIDDLE APEX", CORE BIOPSY: · BENIGN PROSTATE TISSUE G. PROSTATE, LABELED AS "RIGHT MIDDLE BASE", CORE BIOPSY: · BENIGN PROSTATE TISSUE H. PROSTATE, LABELED AS "RIGHT MIDDLE MID", CORE BIOPSY: · BENIGN PROSTATE TISSUE I. PROSTATE, LABELED AS "RIGHT MIDDLE APEX", CORE BIOPSY: · BENIGN PROSTATE TISSUE J. PROSTATE, LABELED AS "RIGHT LATERAL BASE", CORE BIOPSY: · BENIGN PROSTATE TISSUE K. PROSTATE, LABELED AS "RIGHT LATERAL MID", CORE BIOPSY: · PROSTATIC ADENOCARCINOMA, FOAMY GLAND PATTERN · GLEASON GRADE 3+3 · INVOLVING ONE OF ONE CORE, APPROXIMATELY 10% · NO PERINEURAL INVASION · NO LYMPH VASCULAR INVASION L. PROSTATE, LABELED AS "RIGHT LATERAL APEX", CORE BIOPSY: · BENIGN PROSTATE TISSUE

BTW, my wife's mom's family is from Moncks Corner/Goose Creek. August 18th for me. Nervous...but hey, that's normal! I live just north of Moncks Corner.
Posts.Title: I see the newest US News Hospital Rankings are out.....

Posts.Content: Hello all, I'm a 50 year old guy who was recently diagnosed with PC with Gleason 6 after going in for a routine physical. My PSA was 4.1 and the urologist put me on Cipro for a month. After a month I went back to the doctor and the PSA level had dropped to 3.5, but the urologist suggested that I get a biopsy, which I did and found out I had PC on May 14. Several weeks later I went to get a second opinion and was told, unfortunately, that it was Gleason 7. I had studied quite a bit between the initial diagnosis and my second opinion and decided that RP was the way for me to go. I spoke to my second opinion urologist earlier this week and he agreed that this would probably be my best option. He will be doing RALP on me. Anyway, I'm scheduled for surgery on August 18 and obviously a little apprehensive about the whole ordeal. I've never had major surgery before and am just hoping that everything turns out well. Just wanted to pop in, say "hi" and join the club.
Posts.Title: Another newbie...decided on surgery

Posts.Content: I had my 6 week checkup after surgery and have the results from my PSA test...it is .04. Is that a number to be concerned about? Do I just have to hope that it continues a downward trend on follow ups? Is .1 where I should start getting worried? Thanks much.
Posts.Title: PSA levels post surgery

Posts.Content: Thanks guys. My PSA before surgery was 4.1 if that adds anything to the conversation. I go back in January for another PSA test.
Posts.Title: PSA levels post surgery
